captions.text:
Alright, that&#39;s enough retrospective videos.
A wise man once told me, he who dwell on the

past have eyeballs glued to his bum cheeks.
Actually he wasn&#39;t THAT wise. Time to move

on and return our gaze to gaming&#39;s future,
all two or three years of it that remain before

we all die in wars and climate disasters.
And to do that I&#39;m going to review a game

that came out a month ago: Boneworks. Because
it&#39;s VR, which stands for Very Ruturistic.

I&#39;ve been getting back into VR, lately, I
still like it as a fundamentally more immersive

way to play games, but that&#39;s all very well
for me to say from atop my throne of rare

Funkopops. As much as I like playing in VR,
I still don&#39;t think it will become relevant

to the mainstream until (A) it doesn&#39;t cost
so much, (B) the computer you need to run

it on doesn&#39;t cost so much and no longer requires
a cooling system bought second-hand from the

Soviet nuclear program, (C) it can be set
up without taking up nine USB ports and a

day off, and (D) enough time has passed for
everyone to get their sea legs and our futuristic

robot vacuum cleaners have mopped up all the
sick. Oh yes and (E) a couple of hot apps

to make it worth the bother, and Boneworks
might be a right step in that direction.

VR is still largely in its youthful phase
which will inevitably come back to embarrass

it after it leaves high school, meaning that
most of its games are still a bit too enamoured

with the technology itself and based around
short experiences, because they assume the

audience is like the ones in the very early
days of film who screamed when they thought

the big train was about to smash through the
wall, and they&#39;re afraid of overloading the

robot vacuums. Boneworks&#39; story campaign is
largely about being in a VR world and ooh

future technology is humanity ready blah de
blah, disappointingly, but it&#39;s still a step

forward for VR largely because it fucking
has a story campaign of decent length that

isn&#39;t just six rooms in which we stand poking
bananas on a tray until we jizz ourselves.

Also, I can play it sitting down. VR and motion
control games have long had trouble grasping

that comfort is a big part of immersion, and
I don&#39;t like standing around for long periods,

especially not with two pounds of electronics
strapped to me bonce. &#39;Roomscale&#39; my seated

comfortable arse - do you think we all live
in the studio apartments from 90&#39;s sitcoms?

I was enjoying Superhot VR for a while but
then I couldn&#39;t get through a certain level

because they spawned all the guns under me
fucking couch.

But none of that for Boneworks, sit down all
you want you lazy cunt. The next notable thing

is that you move freely around with the analog
stick rather than teleport place to place,

and somehow it doesn&#39;t make me throw up. So
it must be doing something revolutionary,

&#39;cos it&#39;s the kind of game that seems like
it should. It&#39;s a physics-based game where

your in-game body is one of the physics objects,
and you can use your in-game hands to climb

all over the environment, but if you try to
get your in-game hands or head to pass through

a solid object then they won&#39;t, and will judder
violently as the rules of the virtual world

try to meet whatever flappy hands bollocks
you&#39;re doing in reality halfway, and that&#39;s

precisely the kind of shit that overworks
the robot vacuum cleaner, but no, I seem to

be fine. Maybe it&#39;s less the game and more
me being used to VR now, but I hadn&#39;t used

my Oculus for like a year before I started
Boneworks, mainly because I couldn&#39;t be arsed

to set the cameras up again and needed the
USB ports for my powered amphibious bellend

scraper. But when I said the game is physics
based you pictured many things. Hanging ropes

and stacking crates and cabbages and kings.
Boneworks does have a lot of physics puzzling,
i.e. if in doubt, stack a crate,

but it&#39;s physics based in the sense that Half-Life
2 was physics based. In that once you get

bored of all the pulleys and seesaws you can
unwind by admiring the physics with which

a goon&#39;s head bounces off the pavement after
you shoot them with your big gun, and it&#39;s

the combat where Boneworks shines. It&#39;s going
for realism - well, as realistic as you can

get when you&#39;re desperately miming the act
of jerking off a spectacularly well-endowed

man in the hopes that it will make the intangible
fireaxe you&#39;re holding connect with nearby

enemies. And you know, I didn&#39;t think this
could ever work. Swing a melee weapon with

motion controls, the melee weapon bounces
off thing in the game, hands in real life

do not bounce off anything, Oculus Touch controllers
make intimate contact with testicles. But

somehow it works here. Things do get a bit
Jurassic Park Trespasser-y when you&#39;re trying

to heft something the game says is heavy which
in reality weighs the same as everything else,

i.e. bugger all. But it&#39;s the guns that really
do it for me. You have to realistically load

and unload your magazines, realistically pull
back on the slides with your actual hands,

pop the gun under your real actual armpit
to holster it and then listen to it clatter

to the real actual ground half the time because
the holster didn&#39;t register, but it doesn&#39;t matter.

When your rifle runs dry as you&#39;re holding
off attackers so you fling it aside to pull

two pistols out of your armpits and John Woo
your way to safety - well, it&#39;d be hard to

explain how satisfying it feels without getting
placed on a watchlist. I just wish there was

more of it. It takes ages to get to the combat-heavy
parts of the campaign, there&#39;s only one kind

of enemy that also has guns and it&#39;s got the
AI of a startled fish, and thinks the best

approach after you disappear behind cover
is to all cluster around a nearby wall and

examine it for clues. And I hope you like
semi-automatic pistols and submachine guns

&#39;cos that&#39;s your lot. No shotguns, no explosives,
no Ghostbusters laser. I mean, if you&#39;re going

to take influence from Half-Life, I&#39;d have
made the Ghostbusters laser chapter one, personally.

Or possibly even the subtitle. Boneworks even
has its own version of Half-life headcrabs,

incidentally. You can catch them out of the
air as they pounce, then pull out a sidearm

and execute it like you&#39;re spritzing a potplant,
that was also fun, just to add another bullet
point to my watch list entry.

I know only a small percentage of you use
VR and to everyone else I might as well by

telling you how spiffy the handrails are up
in this ivory tower, but for what it&#39;s worth,

Boneworks is the first game in a while to
make me think VR might be getting somewhere.

It&#39;s not there yet. The physics is full of
little niggles as you might expect from a

game trying to juggle so much. The major issue
with the climbing is only your hands and head

can be moved and your in-game legs just flop
around getting in the way of things like two

stubborn trails of cum dangling off your mum&#39;s
chin, but forget all that. Valve announced

that new VR Half-Life Alyx game and immediately
the expectations sprang almost as high as

the stiffies, but on the off-chance that anyone
working on that gives a half-cup of sifted

shit for what I&#39;d like to see, then I point
to Boneworks and say, &quot;Do you see this? Take

this, give it a more coherent plot that doesn&#39;t
just boil down to &quot;It is a VR game&quot; and methinks

doth not protest so much about whether or
not it&#39;s a tech demo, ease off the contrived

physics puzzles and improve the monster and
weapon variety, and that&#39;ll do for me.&quot; &quot;Oh

is that all, Yahtzee? Anything else your expensive
ivory tower escapism device can do to help

you literally blind and deafen yourself to
the ongoing horrors of reality that more and

more of us are forced to live with to the
utter indifference of the openly corrupt liars

and plutocrats that govern our lives, your
imperial bloody majesty?
Er.
Ghostbusters laser?
